Dear [Opposing Counsel's Name],

We are now many months into divorce litigation that Melissa commenced in Delaware County. Throughout this period, and indeed for a significant time leading up to it, the reality of the situation has been starkly different from the narrative your office seems intent on pursuing.

When Melissa made the unilateral decision to abandon the marital residence and, more critically, abandon me during a period of significant vulnerability directly following my diagnosis and treatment for severe Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, she did so without any consideration for the consequences she was imposing. She simply left.

With her departure, she ceased contributing, not just emotionally or maritally, but financially. I did this not because it was equitable or agreed upon, but out of necessity and the responsibility I was abandoned with.

Now, after leaving me to shoulder the full weight of our joint financial obligations and the upkeep of the primary marital asset for this extended period, your client has the audacity to pursue demands that are not only legally questionable but morally bankrupt given her actions. You appear to be operating under the assumption that Melissa's departure and subsequent financial detachment have no bearing on equitable distribution or other financial considerations. Let me disabuse you of that notion immediately.

My position is non-negotiable on this point: I have, through Melissa's abandonment, effectively preserved the marital residence and absorbed all associated costs since her departure. These substantial payments represent my contribution to the marital estate during this period, necessitated by her unilateral decision to leave and contribute nothing. Any equitable distribution analysis must heavily weigh these facts. Furthermore, the concept of spousal support or alimony payable *to* Melissa, given her abandonment during my disability and her subsequent financial non-contribution while I bore all expenses, is frankly astonishing and will be met with the most vigorous opposition.

Consider this my final attempt to inject reality into these proceedings before we are forced to expose the unvarnished truth of Melissa's conduct in open court. I am prepared to litigate this matter fully. I will detail her abandonment, the context of my disability at the time she chose to leave, and the entire financial history since her departure. The record will clearly show who bore the burden and who abdicated their responsibility. A Judge in Delaware County will understand the implications of abandoning a disabled spouse and leaving them to manage the entire financial structure of the marital estate.

This needs to end, and it needs to end fairly, which means acknowledging the reality of the last many months. My proposal is simple and reflects the financial burden I have unfairly carried: I will retain the marital residence, free and clear of any further claim from Melissa, and there will be no spousal support or alimony payable by either party. I have, in effect, already bought out her interest through the expenses I have solely covered since her departure.

If you are unwilling to advise your client to resolve this matter on terms that reflect the reality of her abandonment and my subsequent financial load, then understand that I am prepared to proceed to trial. I will not be extorted or penalized for being the party who stayed and paid while dealing with a disability your client chose to walk away from. The truth will be my defense, and I will present it forcefully and without reservation.

This is not a negotiation based on fantasy or misrepresentation. This is the reality. Adjust your client's expectations accordingly, or prepare for litigation that will leave no stone unturned regarding her conduct and contributions – or lack thereof – over the past many months.

Consider this my definitive statement on the matter. The choice to resolve this based on reality, or to continue down a path that will only lead to increased cost and public revelation of your client's actions, is yours.

Sincerely,

Stephen Boerner
